definitions.definition: A quick breaking or cracking sound or the action of producing such a sound.
A sudden break.
An attempt to seize, bite, attack, or grab.
The act of making a snapping sound by pressing the thumb and an opposing finger of the same hand together and suddenly releasing the grip so that the finger hits against the palm.
A fastening device that makes a snapping sound when used.
A photograph; a snapshot.
definitions.example: We took a few snaps of the old church before moving on.

definitions.definition: The sudden release of something held under pressure or tension.
A thin circular cookie or similar baked good.
A brief, sudden period of a certain weather; used primarily in the phrase cold snap.
A very short period of time (figuratively, the time taken to snap one's fingers), or a task that can be accomplished in such a period.
definitions.example: I can fix most vacuum cleaners in a snap.

definitions.definition: A snap bean such as Phaseolus vulgaris.
A backward pass or handoff of a football from its position on the ground that puts the ball in play; a hike.
(somewhat colloquial) A rivet: a scrapbooking embellishment.
A small meal, a snack; lunch.
A card game, primarily for children, in which players cry "snap" to claim pairs of matching cards as they are turned up.
A greedy fellow.
That which is, or may be, snapped up; something bitten off, seized, or obtained by a single quick movement; hence, a bite, morsel, or fragment; a scrap.
Briskness; vigour; energy; decision
Any circumstance out of which money may be made or an advantage gained. used primarily in the phrase soft snap.
Something that is easy or effortless.
A snapper, or snap beetle.
Jounce (the fourth derivative of the position vector with respect to time), followed by crackle and pop
A quick offhand shot with a firearm; a snap shot.
Something of no value.
A visual message sent through the Snapchat application.
A crisp or pithy quality; epigrammatic point or force.
A tool used by riveters.
A tool used by glass-moulders.
A brief theatrical engagement.
An easy and profitable place or task; a sinecure.
A cheat or sharper.
To fracture or break apart suddenly.
definitions.example: He snapped his stick in anger.

definitions.definition: To give forth or produce a sharp cracking noise; to crack.
To attempt to seize with the teeth or bite.
definitions.example: A dog snaps at a passenger. A fish snaps at the bait.

definitions.definition: To attempt to seize with eagerness.
definitions.example: She snapped at the chance to appear on television.

definitions.definition: To speak abruptly or sharply.
definitions.example: He snapped at me for the slightest mistake.

definitions.definition: To give way abruptly and loudly.
To suffer a mental breakdown, usually while under tension.
definitions.example: She should take a break before she snaps.

definitions.definition: To flash or appear to flash as with light.
To fit or fasten together with a snapping sound.
To jump to a fixed position relative to another element.
definitions.example: The floating toolbar will snap to the edge of the screen when dragged towards it.

definitions.definition: To snatch with or as if with the teeth.
To pull apart with a snapping sound; to pop loose.
To say abruptly or sharply.
To speak to abruptly or sharply; to treat snappishly; usually with up.
To cause something to emit a snapping sound.
To close something using a snap as a fastener.

To snap one's fingers: to make a snapping sound, often by pressing the thumb and an opposing finger of the same hand together and suddenly releasing the grip so that the finger hits against the palm; alternatively, by bringing the index finger quickly down onto the middle finger and thumb.
To cause to move suddenly and smartly.
To take a photograph; to release a camera's shutter (which may make a snapping sound).
definitions.example: He snapped a picture of me with my mouth open and my eyes closed.

definitions.definition: To put (a football) in play by a backward pass or handoff from its position on the ground; to hike (a football).
definitions.example: He can snap the ball to a back twenty yards behind him.

definitions.definition: To misfire.
To catch out sharply (a batsman who has just snicked a bowled ball).
To ward off attacks against; to fight to protect; to guard.
To support by words or writing; to vindicate, talk in favour of.
To make legal defence of; to represent (the accused).
To focus one's energies and talents on preventing opponents from scoring, as opposed to focusing on scoring.
To attempt to retain a title, or attempt to reach the same stage in a competition as one did in the previous edition of that competition.
To call a raise from the big blind.
To ward off, repel (an attack or attacker).
To prevent, to keep (from doing something).
To prohibit, forbid.
To render a representation of something, using words, sounds, images, or other means.
A journey made to a sacred place, or a religious journey.
definitions.example: In the Muslim faith, the pilgrimage to Mecca is known as the Hajj.

definitions.definition: (by extension) A visit to any site revered or associated with a meaningful event.
definitions.example: Each year we made a pilgrimage to New York City to visit the pub where we all first met.

definitions.definition: To go on a pilgrimage.
To assign a quantity to.
To determine the value of (a variable or expression).
Anything that raises or uplifts.
A permanent construction with a built-in platform that is lifted vertically, used to transport people and goods.
A silo used for storing wheat, corn or other grain (grain elevator)
A control surface of an aircraft responsible for controling the pitching motion of the machine.
A dental instrument used to pry up ("elevate") teeth in difficult extractions, or depressed portions of bone.
Any muscle that serves to raise a part of the body, such as the leg or the eye.
A type of shoe having an insert lift to make the wearer appear taller.
The act of substituting or the state of being substituted.
A substitute or replacement.
The replacement of an atom, or group of atoms, in a compound, with another.
